title: 111_hr2421
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Mother's Day Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that Anna Jarvis, founder of modern Mother's Day, was born in Webster, West Virginia on May 1, 1864. She dedicated her life to honoring her mother, Anna Reeves Jarvis, who passed away on May 9, 1905. In 1910, West Virginia Governor William Glasscock issued the first Mother's Day Proclamation. On May 8, 1914, the Sixty-Third Congress approved designating the second Sunday in May as Mother's Day. Res. 263 designates the second Sunday in May as Mother's Day and encourages displaying the American flag at homes as a tribute to mothers. President Woodrow Wilson's 1914 proclamation urged government officials and citizens to show their love and respect for mothers by displaying the flag on this day. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint $1 coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act shall commemorate the 100th anniversary of Mother's Day. The design must include the coin's value, the year "2014", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The Act authorizes the issuance of coins in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2014. The minting authority terminates on December 31, 2014. Sales of the coins may begin before the issuance date. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

(a) Sale Price.--Coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins.

(b) Bulk Sales.--Bulk sales of the coins will be offered at a reasonable discount.

(c) Prepaid Orders at a Discount.--The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for the coins before issuance at a reasonable discount.

SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. The Secretary will add a $10 surcharge per coin sold. The surcharge proceeds will be split equally between the Susan G. Komen for the Cure and the National Osteoporosis Foundation for research purposes. Both organizations will be audited for the funds received. No surcharge can exceed the specified amount. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act if it would exceed the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance on this limitation. SEC. 8. BUDGET COMPLIANCE. The budgetary effects of this Act must comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The determination will be based on the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the House of Representatives. Passed the House of Representatives on May 5, 2010.
